doc.after: The definition of the spatial presence of an entity constrains the possible analysis which can be applied to that entity and influences the final conclusions that can be reached While this property is fundamentally true of all analysis it is particularly important in spatial analysis because the tools to define and study entities favor specific characterizations of the entities being studied Statistical techniques favor the spatial definition of objects as points because there are very few statistical techniques which operate directly on line area or volume elements Computer tools favor the spatial definition of objects as homogeneous and separate elements because of the limited number of database elements and computational structures available and the ease with which these primitive structures can be created
